did.head: Overview of the Collection
did.unittitle: Tinsley Texas Medical Center History Manuscript

repository.label: Repository:
repository.corpname: Special Collections, University of Houston Libraries

did.abstract: The Texas Medical Center: A History of the Founding Years, 1941-1980 is an unpublished photocopied typescript (232 pages) consisting of a Preface, nine chapters, and a bibliography.

bioghist.head: Biographical Information:
bioghist.p: James A. Tinsley was a UH history professor specializing in Texas history for 42 years. In addition, Tinsley served as executive director of the Texas Gulf Coast Historical Association and in that capacity brought the Joseph S. Cullinan papers to UH Special Collections. Tinsley’s publications include The Progressive Movement in Texas and Texas Society of Certified Public Accountants; a history. He also edited Select Letters of Harris Kempner, 1837-1894 and Growth of the Business of Anderson, Clayton & Co. Tinsley died in 2007 at the age of 83.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use:
userestrict.p: Special Collections owns the physical items in our collections, but copyright normally belongs to the creator of the materials or their heirs. The researcher has full responsibility for determining copyright status, obtaining permission to publish from copyright holders, and abiding by current copyright laws when publishing or displaying copies of Special Collections material in print or electronic form. For more information, consult the appropriate librarian. Reproduction decisions will be made by Special Collections staff on a case-by-case basis.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation:
prefercite.p: Tinsley Texas Medical Center History Manuscript, Special Collections, University of Houston Libraries. To cite a specific item from this collection, please consult the most recent edition of your style manual for the proper formatting.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Texas Medical Center: A History of the Founding Years, 1941-1980 is an unpublished photocopied typescript (232 pages) consisting of a Preface, nine chapters, and a bibliography. In this manuscript completed sometime during 1982-83, Tinsley connects the role of local philanthropy, development of federal funding priorities, and the national escalation of focus on cancer research to explain the unique growth and renown of the Texas Medical Center.

Manuscript covers medical center development from 1941 through 1980. Although an unpublished work for hire, this manuscript reflects development of a major facet in Houston’s rise as a city of international significance.
